nodes.text: Land price can contain a rational bubble even when the observed housing rent-to-price ratio is non-vanishing (constant)
Some researchers dismiss rational land or housing bubbles based on empirical stationarity of the observed price-rent (rent-to-price) ratio
Failure to separate pure land rent from housing-structure rent can mask land bubbles because housing rent may be dominated by structure rent

Model: two-period overlapping generations with consumption good and housing service; Cobb-Douglas utility (beta_y, beta_o, beta_h); housing produced by firm using construction material M and land X via production function F(M,X); markets clear and firm maximizes profit rt F(M,X)-M-Dt X
Equilibrium implies the aggregate housing rent-to-price ratio r_t h_t / P_t is constant and equals beta_h / beta_o (Proposition 1)
Using Cobb-Douglas optimal expenditures and land market clearing, land price equals P_t = beta_o e_t (endowment of the young)
Characterization of land bubble (Proposition 2): a land bubble exists iff the sum over time of FX/F evaluated at equilibrium Mt is finite, sum_t FX/F(Mt,1) < infinity
Bubble Characterization Lemma: an asset price exhibits a bubble iff the time series sum of dividend yield Dt/Pt is finite, sum_t Dt/Pt < infinity (used to link FX/F condition to bubbles)
CES example (F CES with elasticity of substitution sigma > 1): asymptotics give FX/F(M,1) ~ constant * M^{1/sigma -1}, implying bubble iff sum_t e_t^{1/sigma -1} < infinity (Proposition 3)
If the economy grows (e_t grows geometrically with rate G>1) then sum_t e_t^{1/sigma -1} converges for sigma>1, so land bubbles inevitably emerge with growth
Conclusion: Observed stationarity or constancy of housing rent-to-price does not rule out land bubbles; one must separate land rent from structure rent to test for land bubbles empirically

Empirical implication and limitation: researchers need to measure or decompose pure land rent versus structure rent to assess existence of land bubbles; current observed housing yield may be dominated by structure rent
Model assumptions on F: F is homogeneous of degree one, continuously differentiable with FM>0, FX>0, concave, and satisfies an Inada-like condition lim_{M->0} (FX/FM)(M,1)=0
